title: Soldier, 21, amputated his own leg so he could save the lives of his crew
text:
The U.S. soldier says he knew that if he didn’t step up, his crew would die (Picture: Corey Toye)

A selfless soldier amputated his own leg to save the lives of crew mates after their tank was involved in a horrific crash.

Ezra Maes, 21, was part of a team taking part in a NATO training exercise in Poland in 2018, when they awoke to realise that their tank was hurtling down a hill at 90mph and none of the brakes were working.

As it dawned on the U.S soldiers that there was nothing they could do, Maes as well as the driver of the tank, Victor Alamo and Sgt. Aechere Crump, the gunner, braced themselves for impact.

The crash sent Victor’s head smashing through the driver’s hatch and broke his back, while Crump ruptured her femoral artery and was bleeding heavily.

Determined to save their lives, Maes began twisting and turning to free his leg which was caught in the turret gear.

As he pulled at his leg, he felt a tearing sensation and only then realised that it was completely gone.

Maes told Fox News: ‘I pushed and pulled at my leg as hard as I could to get loose and felt a sharp tear.

Sgt. Aechere Crump, left and Victor Alamo, right, visit Ezra Maes (Picture: DVIDS)

‘I thought I had dislodged my leg, but when I moved away, my leg was completely gone.’

As blood poured from his wound, Maes forced himself to the back of the tank to grab a medical kit.

He says that he knew if they were to make it out alive, he had to ‘step up’ or that they would all die.

Maes ordered his crew to tie belts around the wounds to stop the bleeding.

Ezra Maes undergoes physical rehabilitation at the Center for the Intrepid, Brooke Army Medical Center’s cutting-edge rehabilitation center at Joint Base San Antonio-Fort Sam Houston, Texas (Picture: Corey Toye/US Army)

The crew also realised that the tank’s communication systems had been destroyed in the crash, and only one cell phone was left in working condition.

Miraculously Maes’ phone began to ring, but he couldn’t reach it.

It was down to the perseverance and determination of Crump, who with a broken leg, tossed Maes the phone, meaning he could text a friend their location.

Ezra Maes says he hopes to help others regain their mobility (Picture: Corey Toye/US Army)

Maes and his crew were eventually rushed to hospital, though he has little recollection of what happened, apart from a memory of his sergeant carrying his leg on a shoulder while running up a hill.

He is currently waiting to be fitted with a prosthetic leg, and is undergoing physical and occupational therapy and tries to stay active by doing yoga three times a week.

Maes also hopes to become a prosthetist and help others regain their mobility, adding that him and his crew ‘are lucky to be alive’.

description: Ezra Maes, 21, pulled at his leg after it became trapped in a horror crash, so he could free himself and save his crew.
